know_your_rights.json.title: Forced Insurance (Bundling)
know_your_rights.json.citation: RBI Master Circular on Customer Service
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks cannot force you to buy insurance, mutual funds, or other products as a condition for getting a loan or a locker.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am being forced to purchase insurance as a condition for my loan/locker. This violates RBI guidelines on bundling and mis-selling. Please process my request without forced products.

know_your_rights.json.title: Locker Loss Compensation
know_your_rights.json.content: The bank is liable for up to 100 times the annual rent if your locker contents are lost due to fire, theft, or building collapse.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am writing to claim compensation for my locker loss as per RBI/2021-22/86. The bank is liable for 100x the annual rent for incidents like fire or theft.

know_your_rights.json.title: Zero Foreclosure Charges
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks and NBFCs cannot charge any penalty for pre-paying floating-rate personal, home, or small business loans taken by individuals.
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to pre-close my floating-rate loan. As per RBI guidelines, no foreclosure charges or pre-payment penalties can be levied on individual borrowers.

know_your_rights.json.title: Dormant Account Rights
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks cannot charge fees for activating a dormant account. KYC for activation can be done at any branch, not just your home branch.
know_your_rights.json.template: I want to reactivate my dormant account. As per RBI/2023-24/105, there should be no charges for activation and KYC can be done at this branch.

know_your_rights.json.title: Return of Property Docs
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks must return original property documents within 30 days of full loan repayment. Delay beyond 30 days carries a 5,000 per day penalty.
know_your_rights.json.template: My loan was closed on [Date]. It has been over 30 days. As per RBI guidelines, I am entitled to my original documents and a compensation of 5,000 per day for the delay.

know_your_rights.json.title: ATM Failed Transaction
know_your_rights.json.content: If money is deducted but not dispensed, the bank must credit it within T+5 days. Beyond that, the bank must pay you 100 for every day of delay.
know_your_rights.json.template: My ATM transaction on [Date] failed but money was deducted. It has been over 5 days. Please credit the amount plus the 100 per day penalty as per RBI rules.

know_your_rights.json.title: Free Look Period
know_your_rights.json.content: You have a right to return an insurance policy within 15 days (30 days for online) if you are not satisfied with the terms.
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to exercise my right to cancel this policy within the Free Look period as per IRDAI Master Circular 2024. Please refund the premium as per rules.

know_your_rights.json.title: Fast Claim Settlement
know_your_rights.json.content: Insurance companies must pay death claims within 15 days of receiving all documents. Any delay beyond that attracts interest penalty.
know_your_rights.json.template: I have submitted all documents for my claim. As per IRDAI 2024 guidelines, the claim must be settled within 15 days. Please expedite or provide interest for delay.

know_your_rights.json.title: EPF Death Claim (7 Days)
know_your_rights.json.content: EPFO must settle death claims within 7 days. For other claims like withdrawal, the timeline is 20 days.
know_your_rights.json.template: I have applied for a death claim for UAN [UAN Number]. As per EPFO Citizen Charter, this must be settled within 7 days. Please check the status.

know_your_rights.json.title: Investor Rights (SCORES 2.0)
know_your_rights.json.content: Stock brokers/AMCs must resolve your grievance within 21 days. If not, you can escalate directly to SEBI via SCORES 2.0.
know_your_rights.json.template: I have a pending grievance with [Broker/AMC Name]. It has been over 21 days. As per SEBI Investor Charter, I am now escalating this for resolution.

know_your_rights.json.title: Doorstep Banking Rights
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks must provide doorstep services (cash pickup/delivery, KYC) to users over 70 years or with disabilities.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am over 70 years old and wish to avail Doorstep Banking services as per RBI/2017-18/89. Please arrange for cash/document services at my residence.

know_your_rights.json.title: Zero-Balance (BSBDA)
know_your_rights.json.content: Every citizen has a right to a Zero-Balance account with no minimum balance penalty and a free ATM card.
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to open a Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account (BSBDA). As per RBI directions, this should be a zero-balance account with no hidden maintenance fees.

know_your_rights.json.title: Zero Liability (Fraud)
know_your_rights.json.content: If you report an unauthorized digital transaction within 3 days, your liability is Zero.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am reporting an unauthorized transaction of [Amount] on [Date]. Since I am reporting within 3 days, my liability is zero as per RBI/2017-18/15. Please credit the amount.

know_your_rights.json.title: Mental Health Cover
know_your_rights.json.content: Insurance companies must cover mental illness treatment on par with physical illness.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am filing a claim for mental health treatment. As per IRDAI/HLT/REG/CIR/046, mental illness must be treated on par with physical illness for insurance coverage.

know_your_rights.json.title: AYUSH Treatment Rights
know_your_rights.json.content: You have the right to claim insurance for Ayurveda, Yoga, Unani, Siddha, and Homeopathy treatments.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am filing a claim for AYUSH treatment. As per IRDAI Master Circular 2024, my policy must cover recognized alternative treatments like Ayurveda/Yoga.

know_your_rights.json.title: Billing Cycle Choice
know_your_rights.json.content: You have the right to choose or change your billing cycle once to suit your needs (e.g., your salary date).
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to change my credit card billing cycle. As per RBI Master Directions on Credit Cards, I have the right to choose a billing cycle that suits my needs.

know_your_rights.json.title: Document Delay Penalty
know_your_rights.json.content: If the bank fails to return property documents within 30 days of loan closure, they must pay you 5,000 for every day of delay.
know_your_rights.json.template: My loan was closed on [Date]. It has been over 30 days. As per RBI/2023-24/60, I am entitled to my original documents and a compensation of 5,000 per day for the delay.

know_your_rights.json.title: Self-Certification Withdrawal
know_your_rights.json.content: You can withdraw PF for illness, marriage, or education via self-certification without needing an employer signature.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am applying for a PF advance for [Purpose]. As per EPFO 2024 guidelines, I am submitting this via self-certification without the need for employer attestation.

know_your_rights.json.title: NPS Partial Withdrawal
know_your_rights.json.content: You can withdraw up to 25% of your contribution for illness, marriage, or home purchase after 3 years of joining NPS.
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to partially withdraw from my NPS account for [Purpose]. As per PFRDA 2024 rules, I am entitled to 25% of my own contribution for this purpose.

know_your_rights.json.title: Negative Balance Bar
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks cannot let your savings account balance go into negative due to non-maintenance of minimum balance.
know_your_rights.json.template: My account balance has been shown as negative due to minimum balance charges. This violates RBI guidelines which prohibit negative balances due to such penalties.

know_your_rights.json.title: Death Claim Delay Penalty
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks must pay a monetary penalty to the nominee if they delay settling a death claim beyond 15 days of receiving all documents.
know_your_rights.json.template: I submitted all documents for the death claim of [Account Name] on [Date]. It has been over 15 days. As per RBI 2025 directions, the bank is now liable to pay a penalty for this delay.

know_your_rights.json.title: Early Exit Refund
know_your_rights.json.content: Effective Oct 2024, you get a significantly higher refund if you surrender your policy early (even in the 1st year).
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to surrender my policy. As per the new IRDAI 2024 norms effective from October 1, 2024, I am entitled to a higher Special Surrender Value.

know_your_rights.json.title: Closure Delay Penalty
know_your_rights.json.content: If the bank doesn't close your credit card within 7 working days of request, they must pay you 500 per day until closure.
know_your_rights.json.template: I requested closure of my card on [Date]. It has been over 7 working days. As per RBI Master Directions, the bank is liable to pay 500 per day for the delay.

know_your_rights.json.title: Interest on Inoperative A/c
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks must continue to credit interest on your savings account at the regular rate even if it is marked as inoperative or inactive.
know_your_rights.json.template: My account was marked inoperative, but interest has not been credited. As per RBI/2023-24/105, banks must credit interest regularly regardless of account status.

know_your_rights.json.title: 10 Nominees Rule
know_your_rights.json.content: You have the right to name up to 10 nominees (increased from 3) for your Mutual Fund folios and Demat accounts.
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to add additional nominees to my account. As per SEBI 2025 guidelines, I am entitled to nominate up to 10 individuals for my investments.

know_your_rights.json.title: Term Deposit (Deceased)
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks cannot charge any penalty for premature closure of FDs/RDs if the account holder has passed away.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am requesting premature closure of the FD of the deceased account holder. As per RBI 2025 directions, no penalty can be levied for such closures.

know_your_rights.json.title: UPI Auto-Reversal
know_your_rights.json.content: For failed UPI payments where money is debited, the bank must reverse it in T+1 days or pay 100 per day penalty.
know_your_rights.json.template: My UPI transaction on [Date] failed but money was debited. It has been over T+1 days. Please credit the amount plus the 100/day penalty as per NPCI rules.

know_your_rights.json.title: Error Correction Penalty
know_your_rights.json.content: If a credit bureau (CIBIL etc.) doesn't fix a wrong entry in 30 days, they must pay you 100 per day compensation.
know_your_rights.json.template: I reported an error in my credit report on [Date]. It has been over 30 days and the error remains. As per RBI/2023-24/72, I am entitled to 100 per day compensation.

know_your_rights.json.title: Key Fact Statement (KFS)
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks must provide a 1-page summary of ALL charges (including hidden fees) before you sign any loan agreement.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am applying for a loan and request a Key Fact Statement (KFS). As per RBI guidelines of April 2024, I must be provided with a transparent summary of all costs.

know_your_rights.json.title: Written Rejection Reason
know_your_rights.json.content: Banks must provide a specific reason in writing or email if they reject your loan application.
know_your_rights.json.template: My loan application was rejected. As per RBI 2025 guidelines, please provide the specific reasons for rejection in writing for my records.

know_your_rights.json.title: Grace Period Right
know_your_rights.json.content: You have a mandatory grace period of 30 days (15 for monthly) to pay premiums before a policy lapses.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am paying my premium within the mandatory grace period. As per IRDAI Master Circular 2024, my policy should not be treated as lapsed.

know_your_rights.json.title: Wallet Balance Refund
know_your_rights.json.content: You have the right to transfer the remaining balance of a digital wallet to your bank account if you close the wallet.
know_your_rights.json.template: I am closing my digital wallet. As per RBI Master Directions, please transfer the remaining balance of [Amount] to my linked bank account.

know_your_rights.json.title: Direct Plan Right
know_your_rights.json.content: You have the right to invest in Direct Plans of Mutual Funds to avoid paying any distributor commission or brokerage.
know_your_rights.json.template: I wish to switch my investments to a Direct Plan. As per SEBI regulations, all mutual funds must offer a direct plan with lower expense ratios.

know_your_rights.json.title: Free Annual Report
know_your_rights.json.content: You are entitled to one full credit report for free every calendar year from each of the major credit bureaus (CIBIL, Experian, Equifax, CRIF).
know_your_rights.json.template: I am requesting my free annual credit report as per RBI/2023-24/72. Every citizen is entitled to one free report per year from each bureau.

meta.description: Deep dive into SGB, Corporate Bonds, G-Secs, and Bond Taxation rules.

sgb_knowledge.title: Sovereign Gold Bonds: The Gold Standard

blocks.title: Last updated & scope
blocks.body: This is a neutral, India-specific compliance guide for SGBs. Rules on taxation, RBI redemption windows, and exchange liquidity can change. Consider verifying tranche documents, RBI FAQs, and your demat statements.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: Understand purchase routes (RBI issue vs secondary market), liquidity constraints, and what tax records to maintain.

items.name: Where you are buying
items.insight: Primary issues (RBI tranche) and secondary market purchases can differ in price discovery and liquidity.

items.name: Exit plan
items.insight: RBI early redemption is typically allowed only after a defined period and on specific dates; exchange sale depends on market liquidity.

items.name: Tax treatment
items.insight: Interest is typically taxable. Capital gains treatment can differ based on how/when you exit. Verify current rules.

blocks.title: Proofs & records to keep
blocks.description: Useful for ITR reporting and reconciliation.

items.name: Demat holding statement
items.note: ISIN, quantity and acquisition details.

items.name: Contract notes (secondary market)
items.note: Brokerage, price and settlement proof.

items.name: Interest credit entries
items.note: Bank statement entries / interest certificates if available.

blocks.title: Liquidity is not guaranteed
blocks.body: Secondary market SGB prices can trade at a discount/premium and volumes can be thin. Consider avoiding reliance on SGB for short-term liquidity needs.

blocks.title: References to consult
blocks.description: For compliance-critical decisions, consider verifying via official sources.

items.name: RBI SGB tranche documents / FAQs
items.note: Issue terms, early redemption windows

items.name: Income-tax guidance
items.note: Interest and capital gains reporting

benefits_decoder.name: Secondary Market Discount
benefits_decoder.insight: SGBs listed on the stock exchange often trade at a discount to the actual gold price due to low liquidity. You can buy them from your Demat account for instant 3-5% profit in gold terms.
benefits_decoder.action: Check exchange prices before subscribing to a new RBI tranche.

benefits_decoder.name: Taxation on Exit
benefits_decoder.insight: Capital Gains are tax-free ONLY if held till maturity (8 years). If sold on exchange before that, LTCG/STCG tax applies. The 2.5% interest is ALWAYS taxable.
benefits_decoder.action: Hold till maturity for best tax efficiency.

liquidity_check.insight: You can surrender the bond to RBI after 5 years on interest payment dates. Or sell on exchange anytime (if you find a buyer).

blocks.title: Last updated & scope
blocks.body: This is a neutral, India-specific compliance guide for corporate bonds. Issuer structures, listing status, taxation and liquidity vary widely. Consider verifying the Information Memorandum (IM), term sheet, and depository records.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: Understand the difference between coupon and yield (YTM), key credit/liquidity risks, and what documents to keep for reporting.

items.name: YTM vs coupon
items.insight: Coupon rate is not the same as your realized return if you buy at premium/discount. Consider checking YTM and accrued interest (dirty price).

items.name: Credit risk beyond ratings
items.insight: Ratings can lag. Consider checking issuer financial health, security/charge, covenants and concentration risk.

items.name: Liquidity / exit
items.insight: Even listed bonds can have low volumes. Your exit price can deviate from fair value.

items.name: Structure (secured/unsecured)
items.insight: Security and seniority matter in stress scenarios. Verify whether the bond is secured and what assets/charge back it.

blocks.title: Proofs & records to keep
blocks.description: These help with ITR reporting and dispute resolution.

items.name: Information Memorandum / term sheet
items.note: Security, covenants, call/put options, and default clauses.

items.name: Demat statements and ISIN mapping
items.note: Holding and corporate action records.

items.name: Contract notes
items.note: Purchase/sale proof for capital gains computation.

items.name: Interest credit entries
items.note: Bank statement entries; may be needed for reconciliation.

blocks.title: Concentration risk
blocks.body: Holding a single issuers bond concentrates risk. Consider diversification and position sizing, especially for lower-rated issuers.

blocks.title: References to consult
blocks.description: For compliance-critical decisions, consider verifying via official sources.

items.name: Issuer/Exchange disclosures
items.note: IM, filings, corporate actions

items.name: Depository statements
items.note: Authoritative ownership and transaction trail

risk_decoder.name: Dirty Price & YTM
risk_decoder.insight: A bond might have a 10% Coupon but if you buy it at a premium (e.g. 1100), your actual return (YTM) is much lower (e.g. 7%). Always calculate Yield To Maturity.
risk_decoder.action: Ignore the Coupon Rate. Look at YTM.

risk_decoder.name: Credit Rating Lag
risk_decoder.insight: Agencies often downgrade a company AFTER it has defaulted. IL&FS was AAA shortly before collapse.
risk_decoder.action: Don't rely solely on ratings. Look at the company's debt levels and cash flow.

structure_check.reason: Secured bonds are backed by assets. In bankruptcy, secured bondholders are paid first. Unsecured/Perpetual bondholders often get nothing.

blocks.title: Last updated & scope
blocks.body: This is a neutral, India-specific guide. Bond taxation depends on listing status, holding period, instrument type, and rule changes. Consider verifying current rules in the Income-tax Act / CBDT notifications and your broker tax statements.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: Understand how interest income and capital gains are typically taxed and what records to keep for reporting.

items.name: Interest income
items.insight: Coupon interest is generally taxable (often at slab rates). Keep bank credits/issuer statements for reconciliation.

items.name: Capital gains
items.insight: Capital gains treatment can depend on listing status and holding period. Verify the current thresholds and rates.

items.name: TDS vs final tax
items.insight: If TDS is deducted, it is not necessarily the final tax. Final liability depends on total income and applicable rates.

blocks.title: Proofs & records to keep
blocks.description: Good recordkeeping reduces mismatch issues during filing.

items.name: Broker capital gains report / tax statement
items.note: Useful starting point; validate against contract notes.

items.name: Contract notes
items.note: Authoritative trade-level buy/sell records.

items.name: Interest credits / certificates
items.note: Bank statement entries and issuer/broker certificates if available.

items.name: AIS/26AS
items.note: Reconcile reported interest/TDS and ensure consistency with your return.

blocks.title: Rule changes happen
blocks.body: Bond capital gains rules and rates can change. Consider checking the latest CBDT/Income-tax guidance for the relevant assessment year.

rules.name: Listed Bonds (Sec 112)
rules.insight: If you sell a listed bond on the exchange after 12 months, profit is taxed at 12.5%. Before 12 months, it is added to income (Slab Rate).
rules.action: Hold for >1 year for tax benefits on price appreciation.

rules.name: Interest Income
rules.insight: The coupon interest you receive annually is added to your income and taxed at slab rate. No special treatment here.
rules.exception: Tax-Free PSU Bonds (NHAI/REC) are the only exception.

meta.description: Comprehensive guide to Term Life, Health Insurance, and ULIPs covering hidden clauses, claim settlement nuances, and agent tactics.

claim_decoder.name: Claim Settlement Ratio (CSR) is Misleading
claim_decoder.insight: CSR counts *number* of claims. A company can pay 99 small claims and reject 1 big claim (yours), still showing 99% CSR. ASR measures the *value* of claims paid.
claim_decoder.action: Check the 'Amount Settlement Ratio' in the IRDAI Annual Report. If CSR is 99% but ASR is 85%, they are rejecting high-value claims.

claim_decoder.name: Section 45 (The 3-Year Ironclad Rule)
claim_decoder.insight: Per Insurance Act Section 45, if a policy is in force for 3 years, the insurer CANNOT reject a claim for any reasonnot even for fraud or non-disclosure of medical history. It becomes indisputable.
claim_decoder.action: Survive the first 3 years! Pay premiums on time. Do not let the policy lapse, or the 3-year clock resets.

claim_decoder.name: MWP Act (Married Women's Property Act)
claim_decoder.insight: If you buy a policy under MWP Act, the claim amount belongs *exclusively* to the wife and children (trustees). Even if you have huge business debts, loans, or go bankrupt, courts/banks CANNOT touch this money.
claim_decoder.action: Crucial for business owners and home loan borrowers. Tick 'Yes' for MWP Act in the proposal form (cannot be done later).

rider_check.reason: Riders cover listed illnesses only at 'advanced stages' (e.g., Cancer of specified severity). A standalone plan often covers early stages and more diseases.
rider_check.recommendation: Avoid Riders if they increase premium significantly. Buy a comprehensive standalone Critical Illness plan.

rider_check.reason: Insurers define 'Accident' strictly. If death occurs 180 days after the accident due to complications, they might deny the claim. Also, it doesn't cover disability.
rider_check.recommendation: A standalone Personal Accident policy covers 'Temporary/Permanent Disability' which is more important than just death benefit.

process_hacks.name: Always Demand a Medical Test
process_hacks.insight: Agents might suggest 'Non-Medical' limits to speed up issuance. Refuse this. A policy issued *after* a medical test is much harder for the insurer to dispute later claiming 'pre-existing condition'.
process_hacks.action: Voluntarily ask for a medical check-up even if the insurer says it's not required.

clause_decoder.name: Room Rent Capping (The Silent Killer)
clause_decoder.insight: If your limit is 5,000/day and you pick a room of 10,000/day, the insurer doesn't just deduct 5,000. They apply 'Proportionate Deduction' to the ENTIRE bill (Doctor fees, OT charges, Nursing) because these are linked to room category.
clause_decoder.action: MANDATORY: Buy a policy with 'No Room Rent Capping' or 'Single Private Room' eligibility. Otherwise, you pay 50% of the entire bill.

clause_decoder.name: Zone-Based Premiums
clause_decoder.risk: Co-pay on Treatment in Higher Zone
clause_decoder.insight: Premiums are cheaper in Tier-2/3 cities (Zone B/C). But if you buy a Zone B policy and get treated in Mumbai/Delhi (Zone A), the insurer imposes a 10-20% Co-pay.
clause_decoder.action: If you live in a small town but plan to go to a metro for major surgeries, buy a Zone A (Metro) policy by paying slightly extra.

clause_decoder.name: Consumables Cover
clause_decoder.insight: Consumables can form 10-15% of a hospital bill (especially post-COVID). Standard policies exclude them.
clause_decoder.action: Ensure your policy has a 'Consumables Benefit' add-on or built-in feature.

clause_decoder.name: Restoration / Refill Benefit
clause_decoder.insight: Most plans restore sum insured only for *unrelated* illnesses. If you have a relapse of the *same* illness in the same year, the basic restoration won't pay.
clause_decoder.action: Look for 'Unlimited Restoration' that works for 'Same Person, Same Illness' as well.

super_topup_hack.title: The Super Top-up Strategy
super_topup_hack.concept: High Coverage at Dirt Cheap Rates
super_topup_hack.example: Instead of a 20 Lakh Corporate/Retail plan costing 25k, buy a 5 Lakh Base Plan (8k) + 15 Lakh Super Top-up (3k). Total 11k.
super_topup_hack.mechanism: Super Top-up covers ANY claim amount above the 'Deductible' (e.g., 5L). It looks at the *aggregate* claims in a year, unlike a standard Top-up which looks at *single* claim.
super_topup_hack.action: Base Plan of 5L is sufficient for minor issues. Super Top-up takes care of major catastrophic events.

ayush_treatment.title: AYUSH & Modern Treatment Limits
ayush_treatment.insight: Many policies cap Ayurveda/Homeopathy (AYUSH) at 10-20% of Sum Insured. Similarly, Robotic Surgeries or Cyber Knife treatments often have 'sub-limits'.
ayush_treatment.action: Check the 'Sub-limits' column in the policy wording specifically for Modern Treatments.

fee_decoder.name: Premium Allocation Charge
fee_decoder.insight: A percentage of your premium (2-5%) is deducted straight away before investment. In the first year, this is highest to pay distributor commissions.
fee_decoder.action: Direct Mutual Funds have 0% entry load. 100% of your money is invested.

fee_decoder.name: Mortality Charge (The Age Tax)
fee_decoder.insight: Insurers deduct units monthly to provide life cover. As you get older, mortality risk rises, so they sell MORE of your units to pay for insurance. This eats into compounding returns significantly in later years.
fee_decoder.action: Don't mix insurance with investment. Term Plan premiums are fixed for life. ULIP mortality charges rise with age.

fee_decoder.name: Policy Admin Charges
fee_decoder.insight: A flat monthly fee deducted from your fund value, regardless of performance.
fee_decoder.action: Compare 'Reduction in Yield' (RIY). If RIY > 1.5%, the ULIP is expensive.

tax_reality.insight: If annual premium exceeds 2.5 Lakh, the maturity proceeds are TAXABLE as Capital Gains (12.5% LTCG) just like Mutual Funds. The 'Tax-Free' advantage is gone for HNI investors.
tax_reality.action: Check the issuance date. Policies bought after Feb 1, 2021 fall under this rule.

meta.description: Deep dive into FD, RD, Mutual Funds, and Corporate FDs focusing on taxation, DICGC safety, hidden commissions, and exit loads.

fee_decoder.name: The 5 Lakh Safety Limit
fee_decoder.insight: Bank deposits are insured by DICGC only up to 5 Lakh per bank per user (Principal + Interest). If a Co-operative bank fails, you lose anything above 5 Lakh.
fee_decoder.action: Split deposits > 5 Lakh across different banks (e.g., SBI, HDFC, ICICI) to stay fully insured.

fee_decoder.name: Premature Withdrawal Penalty
fee_decoder.insight: If you break an FD before maturity, banks deduct 1% from the *applicable* rate (rate for the period FD actually ran), not just the contracted rate.
fee_decoder.action: Avoid breaking FDs. Use a 'Loan Against FD' or Overdraft (usually 1-2% interest above FD rate).

fee_decoder.name: Corporate FDs
fee_decoder.insight: Company FDs (like Shriram, Bajaj) offer higher rates but are UNSECURED. DICGC insurance does NOT apply. If the company defaults, you lose 100%.
fee_decoder.action: Stick to AAA-rated Corporate FDs only. Never chase the highest rate.

fee_decoder.name: RD Delayed Installment
fee_decoder.insight: Missing an RD date is expensive. Banks charge a penalty for every day/month of delay and may reduce the final interest payout.
fee_decoder.action: Set the RD deduction date 2-3 days *after* your salary date.

fee_decoder.name: Form 15G/15H Reality
fee_decoder.insight: Submitting 15G stops TDS deduction (10%), but it does NOT make the interest tax-free. You still have to pay tax if your total income exceeds the basic exemption limit.
fee_decoder.action: Check your total tax liability before submitting 15G to avoid penalties.

smart_checks.explanation: Auto-sweep gives FD returns on savings balance. But if the sweep is broken (money used) within 7 days, you often earn ZERO interest on that chunk.
smart_checks.recommendation: Keep a buffer in savings. Let only true surplus go to Auto-Sweep.

smart_checks.explanation: Banks often auto-renew FDs for the same tenure. If rates have dropped, you get locked into a lower rate automatically.
smart_checks.recommendation: Set maturity instruction to 'Auto-Credit to Savings Account' so you can decide the best new tenure manually.

smart_checks.term: Mode of Operation: Either or Survivor
smart_checks.explanation: If holding is 'Jointly', both signatures are needed for everything. In 'E or S', either survivor can manage it easily.
smart_checks.recommendation: Always choose 'Either or Survivor' (E or S) for joint FDs.

fee_decoder.name: The 1% Commission Gap
fee_decoder.insight: Agents sell 'Regular Plans' to earn ~1% commission every year from your corpus. Over 20 years, this 1% difference can reduce your final corpus by 20-30 Lakhs.

fee_decoder.name: Expense Ratio Impact
fee_decoder.insight: This is the annual fee deducted from your NAV. A fund with 2% expense ratio needs to generate 14% gross return just to give you 12% net.
fee_decoder.action: Compare expense ratios of similar funds. Lower is usually better for Index/Debt funds.

fee_decoder.name: Exit Load
fee_decoder.insight: A penalty for leaving early. Most equity funds charge 1% if you withdraw before 365 days.
fee_decoder.action: Do not use Equity SIPs for money needed in < 1 year. Use Liquid Funds (Zero Exit Load).

fee_decoder.name: Stamp Duty
fee_decoder.insight: A tiny government levy deducted upfront from every SIP installment.

fee_decoder.name: Arbitrage Funds (The Tax Hack)
fee_decoder.insight: Arbitrage funds are taxed as Equity (12.5% LTCG) but behave like Debt/FD (Low risk). For people in the 30% tax bracket, Arbitrage funds are far better than FDs post-tax.
fee_decoder.action: Use Arbitrage Funds for parking money for 6 months to 1 year.

tax_decoder.name: Equity STCG (< 1 Year)
tax_decoder.insight: Profit booked before 1 year is taxed heavily at 20%.
tax_decoder.strategy: Avoid redeeming equity funds before 1 year unless it's an emergency.

tax_decoder.name: Equity LTCG (> 1 Year)
tax_decoder.insight: Profits over 1.25 Lakh in a financial year are taxed at 12.5%.
tax_decoder.strategy: Tax Harvesting: Book profits up to 1.25L every year to pay zero tax, then reinvest.

tax_decoder.name: Debt Fund Taxation (Post-2023)
tax_decoder.insight: Indexation benefit is REMOVED for debt funds bought after April 1, 2023. They are now taxed exactly like FDs (at your slab rate).
tax_decoder.strategy: For long term debt allocation, SGB or PPF/EPF is now much more tax-efficient than Debt Mutual Funds.

red_flags.reason: Dividends are now fully taxable at your income slab. Growth option is much more tax-efficient.
NFOs at 10 NAV are not 'cheaper'. They have no track record.
red_flags.action: Stick to existing funds with >5 year track records.

red_flags.reason: BAFs charge high fees (~2%) for managing asset allocation. Often, a simple 50:50 mix of Nifty Index + Liquid Fund performs better at lower cost.

document_checklist.note: Download CAS from CAMS/KFintech once a year to see all your MF holdings in one view.
Mutual Fund folios without nominees are frozen. Check status immediately.
For SIP auto-debit. Ensure signature matches bank records to avoid rejection.
Check strictly on CVL KRA website. 'KYC Registered' is mandatory.

meta.description: The ultimate guide to Home Loans: RLLR mechanics, Prepayment math, Hidden charges, Fraud prevention, and Negotiation scripts.

interest_rate_decoder.title: Interest Rates: RLLR vs MCLR
interest_rate_decoder.description: Understanding how your interest rate is calculated is the first step to saving money.

items.insight: RLLR = Repo Rate + Spread. When RBI cuts Repo Rate, banks MUST pass it on to you within 3 months. This is mandatory for all new floating rate retail loans since Oct 2019.
items.action: Ensure your loan is on RLLR, not MCLR.

items.insight: While Repo Rate is external, the 'Spread' is decided by the bank based on your credit risk. Banks insert a clause to 'Reset Spread' every 3 years. They use this to increase your rate even if Repo stays same.
items.action: Read the 'Reset Period' clause in your agreement. Longer reset periods (e.g. 5 years) are safer.

items.insight: If you are on an old high-interest regime (MCLR/Base Rate), you can switch to the new RLLR regime within the SAME bank by paying a 'Conversion Fee' (usually 2000-5000 + GST).
items.action: If your rate is > 0.5% above current offer rates, ask for a Conversion immediately.

prepayment_strategy.title: Prepayment: Kill the Loan Early
prepayment_strategy.description: How to become debt-free in 10 years instead of 20.

items.reason: When you prepay, banks ask: 'Do you want to reduce EMI or Tenure?'. Reducing Tenure saves lakhs in interest. Reducing EMI just eases monthly cashflow but keeps you in debt longer.
items.action: Tick 'Reduce Tenure' on the prepayment form.

items.insight: If you prepay just 10% of the outstanding principal once a year (e.g., using your bonus), you can close a 20-year loan in just ~10 years.
If you can't afford big prepayments, just paying 1 extra EMI equivalent every year (13 EMIs in a year) cuts ~3-4 years off a 20-year loan.

insurance_trap.title: The Insurance Bundling Trap
insurance_trap.description: Distinguishing between Mandatory and Optional covers.

items.insight: Banks legally require you to insure the *structure* of the house (against fire/earthquake) to protect their collateral. Cost is cheap (3-5k for 10 years).
items.action: Buy it. You can buy it from any insurer, not just the bank's partner.

items.insight: This covers your life. If you die, it pays the loan. Banks push this aggressively as a 'Single Premium' added to your loan amount. You pay interest on this premium!
items.action: REJECT IT. A standard Term Insurance plan is 5x cheaper and gives better coverage.

fee_decoder.title: The Real Cost: Visible & Hidden Fees
fee_decoder.description: Beyond interest, these are the charges you need to budget for.

charges.name: The 'Spread' Game (RLLR)
charges.insight: Your Rate = Repo Rate + Spread. Repo changes for everyone, but 'Spread' is specific to YOU. Banks often increase the Spread silently later (reset clause).
charges.action: Ensure the 'Spread' is constant for the loan tenure in your Sanction Letter.

charges.name: Processing Fee (PF)
charges.insight: Highly Negotiable! Ask for a 50-100% waiver during festive offers. Never pay this in cash to an agent.

charges.name: MODT / Notice of Intimation
charges.insight: Maharashtra caps this at 30k. Karnataka at 0.5%. Builders often collect 'Legal Fees' in cash which includes thisverify the actual government receipt.

charges.name: Legal & Valuation Charges
charges.insight: Paid to 3rd party lawyers/engineers. Ask if this is included in the Processing Fee or extra.

charges.name: Franking / Stamp Duty
charges.insight: State government tax on loan contract execution. Mandatory and non-negotiable.

charges.name: CIBIL / CERSAI Fees
charges.insight: Some banks charge 50 CERSAI fee with *every* construction-linked disbursement. Over 20 disbursements, this adds up.

charges.name: Login / Application Fee
charges.insight: Covers initial admin costs. Usually non-refundable even if loan is rejected. Demand a receipt.

safety_protocol.title: Fraud Prevention & Smart Moves
safety_protocol.description: Critical rules to avoid scams and bad deals.

checklist.explanation: Processing fees, login fees, or 'verification charges' should never be paid in cash to an agent.
Cheques must be payable to 'Bank Name - Loan Account'. Never issue cheques to an individual's name.
If an agent asks for a personal commission to 'guarantee' approval, it is a scam. Loan approvals are centralized.
Only switch banks if the new rate is >0.50% lower. The switching cost (PF + MODT + Valuation) consumes about 0.5% of the benefit.
Before switching, email your current bank: 'I am getting X% from Bank B. Match it or I close.' They often reduce your rate for a small conversion fee (2k-5k).
Every time you formally apply for a loan, your CIBIL drops by a few points. Do not apply to 5 banks at once. Shop around informally first.
Every payment must have a printed receipt with a Transaction ID.

common.note: CRITICAL. When depositing property papers, demand an official 'LOD' on bank letterhead. You need this to get papers back.
If doing a Balance Transfer, the existing bank will delay this. Escalate to Nodal Officer if delayed > 7 days.
PAN, Aadhaar (Address must match residence or provide Rent Agreement).
Keep one cheque ready favoring the lender.

salaried.note: Last 6 months (Salary account). Ensure no cheque bounces.

self_employed.note: GST Registration / Shop Act (min 3 years vintage).

property_documents.note: Chain of ownership for past 13-30 years.

clauses.norm: Banks add 1-2L 'Loan Protection Policy' to your loan. You pay interest on this premium for 20 years! It is OPTIONAL per RBI.
clauses.action: Reject it. Use your existing Term Insurance (5x cheaper).

clauses.red_flag: Clause allowing bank to change 'Spread' arbitrarily
clauses.norm: Only Repo Rate should change. Spread should remain constant.
clauses.action: Ask agent: 'Is the Spread fixed for the entire tenure?'

clauses.norm: RBI Mandate: ZERO penalty for floating rate home loans for individuals.
Penalty for missed EMIs is typically 2% per month (24% p.a.) on the overdue amount.
clauses.action: Be aware of this high cost of bouncing a cheque.

clauses.norm: Sometimes loans are sanctioned but money isn't released due to property issues.
clauses.action: Ensure sanction is 'Unconditional' before paying builder booking amount.

agent_script.title: Negotiation Scripts
questions: What is the Repo Spread? Is it fixed for the entire tenure?
Is the Loan Insurance mandatory? Please show me the RBI circular.
Can you waive 50% of the processing fee?
Can you show me the official MODT charges receipt from the Sub-Registrar?
If I pre-pay part of the loan, will you reduce the Tenure or the EMI?

od_flexi_knowledge.title: OD / Flexi Loan: How to Use It Safely (India)

blocks.title: Scope & disclaimer
blocks.body: This page is a neutral, compliance-oriented guide for overdraft (OD) / flexi loans in India. Exact terms vary by lender and product (home loan OD, loan against property OD, business OD, etc.). Consider verifying your sanction letter and bank statements for the definitive rules.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: Understand how OD/flexi interest is charged, what to check in statements, and which clauses/fees typically cause surprises.

items.name: How interest is calculated
items.insight: OD interest is usually calculated on the outstanding balance (often daily) and debited periodically. Confirm the lenders method and debit cycle in your statement.

items.name: Rate linkage & reset
items.insight: Check whether the rate is linked to an external benchmark (repo/RLLR) or internal benchmark (MCLR/base rate) and how often the spread/margin can be reset.

items.name: Renewal / review
items.insight: Many OD lines have periodic renewal/review where limits, fees, or spreads can change. Check the renewal schedule and fees in your sanction letter.

items.name: Minimum servicing
items.insight: Some OD/flexi products require a minimum monthly deposit/interest servicing. Missing it can trigger penal interest or downgrade.

blocks.title: Documents to keep
blocks.description: For disputes, refinancing, or tax/compliance queries, these documents usually matter more than screenshots.

items.name: Sanction letter / facility agreement
items.note: ROI linkage, spread reset clause, renewal terms, fees, and minimum servicing.

items.name: Account statements
items.note: Interest debit entries, charges, penal interest, and rate changes.

items.name: Schedule / key fact statement (if provided)
items.note: Any formal disclosures the lender provides.

items.name: Fee/charge receipts
items.note: Processing/renewal fees and any one-time charges.

blocks.title: Common operational risk
blocks.body: OD can feel like extra money because of a revolving limit. Consider tracking the outstanding like a normal loan principal; otherwise, it can remain open indefinitely with only interest servicing.

blocks.title: Common surprises (and what to verify)
blocks.description: These are not always wrongtheyre often buried in product terms.

items.name: Annual renewal / review fees
items.insight: Some lenders charge periodic renewal fees or ask for updated documents. Verify the fee schedule and who can change it.

items.name: Spread/margin reset
items.insight: Even if the benchmark stays flat, a spread reset can raise your effective rate. Check if the spread is fixed for the tenure or resettable.

items.name: Charges for non-maintenance of minimum balance / servicing
items.insight: Some products impose charges or penal interest if you do not service interest or maintain a minimum deposit pattern.

items.name: Foreclosure / conversion charges
items.insight: If you switch products (OD to term loan, or vice versa) within the same bank, there may be conversion fees.

blocks.title: References to consult
blocks.description: For disputes, consider verifying using official banking grievance and RBI guidance pathways.

items.name: Your lenders sanction letter / KFS
items.note: The authoritative terms for your OD/flexi.

items.name: RBI: Customer grievance / Ombudsman framework
items.note: Escalation pathway if a bank response is unsatisfactory.

meta.description: Educational content for Government Retirement Schemes (EPF, NPS, PPF) focusing on hidden clauses, tax traps, and optimization.

blocks.title: Last updated & scope
blocks.body: This is a neutral, India-specific compliance guide for EPF/UPF. Exact portal flows and employer processes can vary. Consider verifying with EPFO guidance, your employers HR process, and your UAN portal details.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: Understand EPF vs EPS split, transfer vs withdrawal implications, common compliance/tracking pitfalls, and what documents to keep.

items.name: EPF vs EPS split
items.insight: Employer contribution is not always fully credited to EPF. A portion can go to EPS as per rules and caps.

items.name: Job change: transfer vs withdrawal
items.insight: Withdrawing before meeting eligibility conditions can create tax complexity. Transferring helps maintain service continuity.

items.name: VPF/large contributions
items.insight: High employee contributions can have additional tax reporting implications beyond certain thresholds.

blocks.title: Proofs & records to keep
blocks.description: These are useful for reconciliation, job switches, and resolving employer/EPFO discrepancies.

items.name: UAN and KYC status
items.note: Ensure PAN/Aadhaar/bank are linked; keep screenshots/acknowledgements where applicable.

items.name: EPF passbook and member details
items.note: Download periodically; useful for service history and contributions.

items.name: Payslips / employer contribution breakup
items.note: Helps verify whether contributions are as expected (EPF vs EPS).

items.name: Transfer/claim acknowledgements
items.note: Keep claim reference numbers for transfer/withdrawal requests.

blocks.title: Common mismatch source
blocks.body: EPF issues often come from incomplete KYC/UAN mapping or multiple PF accounts not linked/merged. Consider reconciling UAN-linked member IDs when switching jobs.

blocks.title: Common mistakes to avoid
blocks.description: These often lead to delays, tax issues, or lost interest.

items.name: Withdrawing EPF during job switch
items.insight: May break continuity and can trigger tax implications depending on service period and circumstances.

items.name: Not checking passbook after employer changes
items.insight: Contributions can be delayed or mapped to a different member ID; periodic checks reduce surprises later.

items.name: Ignoring inactive/unmerged accounts
items.insight: Multiple member IDs or unmerged accounts can complicate claims and interest crediting.

blocks.title: References to consult
blocks.description: For compliance-critical decisions, consider verifying using official EPFO guidance.

items.name: EPFO Member Portal / UAN services
items.note: KYC, passbook, claims and service history

items.name: Employer HR/Payroll policies
items.note: Contribution basis and transfer process

salary_decoder.name: The 'Pension' Diversion
salary_decoder.rule: 12% Employer Share is NOT fully EPF
salary_decoder.insight: Out of your employer's 12% share, 8.33% goes to the Pension Scheme (EPS) (capped at 1,250/mo) and only 3.67% goes to your EPF corpus.
salary_decoder.action: Don't calculate 24% of Basic as your EPF corpus. It's actually ~15.67% + Fixed Pension.

salary_decoder.name: VPF Taxation (> 2.5 Lakh)
salary_decoder.insight: If your own contribution (EPF + VPF) exceeds 2.5 Lakh in a financial year, the interest earned on the *excess* amount is taxable at your slab rate. Two separate PF accounts are maintained for this.
salary_decoder.action: Limit VPF if you are in the 30% bracket and want to avoid tax complexity.

tax_traps.name: The 5-Year Service Rule
tax_traps.explanation: If you withdraw EPF before completing 5 years of *continuous* service, the entire amount becomes taxable, and previously claimed 80C deductions are reversed.
tax_traps.recommendation: Never withdraw during job switches. Always 'Transfer' your EPF to the new employer to keep the 5-year counter running.

process_checks.note: Ensure all previous company PF accounts are merged into your current UAN. Unmerged accounts stop earning interest after 3 years of inactivity.

blocks.title: Last updated & scope
blocks.body: This is a neutral, India-specific compliance guide for PPF. Exact process and forms can vary slightly by bank/post office and may change with notifications. Consider verifying the latest rules and your institutions process before acting.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: Understand deposit timing rules, maturity/extension paperwork, liquidity (loan/withdrawal) windows, and what proofs to keep for compliance.

items.name: Deposit timing
items.insight: PPF interest is typically computed on the lowest balance between the 5th and the last day of the month. Depositing after the 5th can reduce interest for that month.

items.name: Annual contribution limits
items.insight: PPF has minimum and maximum annual contribution limits. Consider checking current limits before contributing large amounts.

items.name: Maturity action
items.insight: At maturity (15 years), you may need to submit the correct form within the allowed window to extend with contributions. Missing the window can change how the account behaves.

blocks.title: Proofs & records to keep
blocks.description: These help during account service requests, nominee changes, and in case your institution asks for supporting documents.

items.name: PPF statement / passbook
items.note: Keep annual statement or passbook entries for deposits and interest postings.

items.name: Deposit receipts
items.note: If deposits are made offline, keep receipts; for online, keep reference numbers/screenshots until reflected in statement.

items.name: Nomination details
items.note: Keep nominee acknowledgement; update after life events.

items.name: Extension paperwork
items.note: If extending after maturity, keep the submitted form acknowledgement from the bank/post office.

blocks.title: Common operational mistake
blocks.body: Many account issues happen because extension/closure forms are not submitted (or are submitted late) at maturity. Consider tracking your maturity date and the allowed submission window.

blocks.title: Liquidity windows (loan / withdrawal)
blocks.description: PPF is not fully liquid. Consider checking the applicable year-based windows before relying on it for emergencies.

items.name: Loan against PPF
items.insight: Loans are typically allowed only in specific years (commonly between year 3 and year 6). The exact eligibility and limit is institution/rule dependent.

items.name: Partial withdrawal
items.insight: Partial withdrawals are typically allowed after a lock-in period and can have limits based on balance in earlier years.

blocks.title: Common mistakes to avoid
blocks.description: These are common reasons users lose interest or face process delays.

items.name: Depositing after the 5th
items.insight: Can reduce interest for that month depending on the interest computation method.

items.name: Assuming maturity happens automatically
items.insight: Extension with contributions may require a form submission within a defined window.

items.name: Treating PPF as emergency cash
items.insight: Liquidity is limited; loans/withdrawals have eligibility rules and timelines.

items.name: Not updating nominee
items.insight: Nomination problems can create delays for heirs and additional documentation needs.

blocks.title: References to consult
blocks.description: For compliance-critical actions (extension/withdrawal), consider verifying via your institutions official process and published FAQs.

items.name: Your bank/Post Office PPF FAQs
items.note: Forms, timelines and branch process

items.name: Government/official PPF rules (as notified)
items.note: Current limits and eligibility

optimization_hacks.name: The '5th of the Month' Rule
optimization_hacks.insight: Interest is calculated on the lowest balance between the 5th and the last day of the month. If you deposit on the 6th, you lose interest for the whole month.
optimization_hacks.action: Set your SIP/Standing Instruction for the 1st of every month.

optimization_hacks.name: Maturity Extension (15+5)
optimization_hacks.insight: After 15 years, you can extend PPF by 5 years *with* contributions. This continues the EEE (Exempt-Exempt-Exempt) status. This is the best way to build a tax-free retirement corpus.
optimization_hacks.action: Submit Form H within 1 year of maturity to extend.

liquidity_decoder.name: Loan Against PPF
liquidity_decoder.insight: You can take a loan at just +1% interest rate against your PPF balance. Extremely cheap credit compared to Personal Loans (12-15%).

blocks.title: Last updated & scope
blocks.body: This is a neutral, India-specific compliance guide for NPS. Rules around exit, annuity purchase, and tax treatment can change with notifications. Consider verifying with PFRDA/CRA guidance and your account statements before acting.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: Understand Tier 1 vs Tier 2 differences, exit/annuity constraints, documentation to keep, and common reporting pitfalls.

items.name: Tier 1 vs Tier 2
items.insight: Tier 1 is retirement-focused with constraints; Tier 2 is generally more liquid but may not provide the same tax treatment.

items.name: Exit rules
items.insight: At retirement age, you may need to allocate a portion to annuity as per rules. Consider checking how this impacts post-retirement taxation.

items.name: Proofs for tax benefits
items.insight: If you claim deductions, keep contribution receipts/CRA statements that substantiate the claim.

blocks.title: Proofs & records to keep
blocks.description: These help for deductions, reconciliation, and CRA service requests.

items.name: PRAN details and CRA statements
items.note: Periodic statements showing contributions, holdings and transactions.

items.name: Contribution receipts
items.note: Keep payment reference/receipt; useful if a contribution is not reflected.

items.name: Annuity purchase documents (at exit)
items.note: Policy/annuity documents and payout details.

blocks.title: Annuity payouts can be taxable
blocks.body: NPS is not uniformly tax-free end-to-end. Depending on rules and your situation, annuity income can be taxable. Consider accounting for this in retirement planning and documentation.

blocks.title: Common mistakes to avoid
blocks.description: These are common issues seen in account maintenance and exit handling.

items.name: Confusing Tier 2 as same as MF for taxes
items.insight: Operationally similar in liquidity, but tax treatment and reporting may differ. Verify current rules.

items.name: Not keeping CRA statements/receipts
items.insight: Without receipts, reconciliation and deduction substantiation becomes harder.

items.name: Ignoring exit constraints
items.insight: Exit/withdrawal can have constraints such as annuity purchase requirements; verify before planning liquidity.

blocks.title: References to consult
blocks.description: For compliance-critical actions (exit/annuity), consider verifying via official sources.

items.name: PFRDA / CRA official guidance
items.note: Exit rules, KYC and contribution processes

items.name: Your CRA account statements
items.note: Authoritative record of contributions and holdings

fee_decoder.name: NPS Tier 2 vs Mutual Funds
fee_decoder.insight: Tier 2 has NO lock-in and very low fund management charges (0.01%). However, it has NO tax benefits. Mutual Funds are easier to manage and offer better liquidity.
fee_decoder.action: Stick to Tier 1 for retirement. Use Mutual Funds for other goals.

fee_decoder.name: The Annuity Lock (The 40% Rule)
fee_decoder.insight: At age 60, you CANNOT withdraw 100% money. You must buy an Annuity (Pension Plan) for at least 40% of the corpus. The pension you receive is **Taxable** at slab rates.
fee_decoder.action: Factor this taxation into your retirement planning. NPS is not fully tax-free like PPF.

smart_choices.name: Auto vs Active Choice
smart_choices.reason: Auto choice reduces equity exposure conservatively as you age. If you have other debt assets (EPF/PPF), keep NPS aggressive (75% Equity) till age 60 for max growth.

concepts.name: The Rule of 25
concepts.insight: If your annual expense is 10 Lakhs, you need 2.5 Crores to retire. This assumes a safe withdrawal rate of 4% per year.
concepts.action: Calculate your expenses accurately, including occasional big spends.

concepts.name: The 4% Withdrawal Rule
concepts.rule: Withdraw 4% initially, then adjust for inflation
concepts.insight: Historically, a balanced portfolio allows you to withdraw 4% of the initial corpus (adjusted for inflation) for 30 years without running out of money. In India's high inflation, 3% is safer.
concepts.action: Be conservative. Aim for 30x or 35x expenses if retiring very early (40s).

strategies.name: Bucket Strategy
strategies.insight: Divide corpus into 3 buckets: 1) Immediate (Cash/FD for 3 yrs), 2) Medium Term (Debt/Hybrid for 3-10 yrs), 3) Long Term (Equity for 10+ yrs growth).
strategies.action: Don't keep everything in FD (inflation risk) or Equity (market risk).

checklist.note: Crucial. Unclaimed PF/Pension money is huge in India. Ensure nominees are current.

meta.description: Educational content for Income Tax planning, Tax Regimes, and Capital Gains rules with advanced strategies.

regime_knowledge.title: Old vs New Tax Regime: The Math

blocks.title: Last updated
blocks.body: This page is based on Indian income-tax rules as of the last app content update. Tax rules, slabs, standard deduction and deduction eligibility can change in a Budget or via notifications. Consider verifying with the latest Income-tax Department guidance before filing.

blocks.title: What this helps with
blocks.description: A neutral checklist to decide which regime to choose for the current year and what proofs to keep so your return is defensible.

items.name: Decision framing
items.note: How to compare regimes without guesswork

items.name: Proofs & documents
items.note: What payroll/ITR may ask for (HRA/80C/80D/home-loan etc.)

items.name: Common mistakes
items.note: Frequent reasons for mismatch between Form 16, AIS/26AS and your return

blocks.title: Quick decision checklist (neutral)
blocks.description: Consider these questions before choosing a regime. This is not tax advice; it is a compliance-oriented checklist.

items.name: Do you have claimable deductions/exemptions?
items.insight: If you plan to claim items like HRA, 80C/80D, home-loan interest, etc., the old regime may be relevant. If you do not claim many deductions, the new regime may be simpler and sometimes lower.

items.name: Can you produce proofs if asked?
items.insight: Even if your employer accepted declarations, you may need to produce evidence later (rent receipts, premium receipts, interest certificates, donation receipts).

items.name: Are you salaried, self-employed, or both?
items.insight: The opt-in/opt-out mechanics and constraints can differ for different taxpayer types. Consider reviewing the ITR instructions for your form.

items.name: Are your numbers consistent across Form 16, AIS and 26AS?
items.insight: Before filing, reconcile income, TDS, interest, and capital gains across sources to reduce mismatch notices.

blocks.title: Proofs to keep (India compliance)
blocks.description: A practical list of documents commonly needed for deductions/exemptions and reconciliations.

items.name: Form 16
items.note: Keep Part A and Part B. Verify employer PAN/TAN and breakup of exemptions/deductions.

items.name: AIS / TIS and Form 26AS
items.note: Use these to reconcile salary, interest, dividends, capital gains, and TDS.

items.name: HRA
items.note: Rent receipts, rent agreement (if applicable), proof of rent payment (bank transfer), and landlord PAN where required.

items.name: 80C
items.note: EPF/PPF statements, ELSS statement, life insurance premium receipts, tuition fee receipts, principal repayment certificate (if claimed).

items.name: 80D
items.note: Health insurance premium receipt showing policyholder/insured persons and mode of payment.

items.name: Home loan interest (if applicable)
items.note: Interest certificate from lender and property completion/possession status where relevant.

items.name: Other income
items.note: Bank interest certificates/statement for savings/FD interest, dividend statements, and brokerage contract notes where applicable.

blocks.title: TDS is not final tax
blocks.body: TDS deduction does not automatically mean your tax is fully settled. Final tax liability depends on total income, deductions, and regime choice. Reconcile and compute before filing.

blocks.title: Common mistakes that cause notices or rework
blocks.description: These are common operational issues seen in filings; consider checking them before submitting your ITR.

items.name: Mismatch between Form 16 and AIS/26AS
items.insight: Interest/dividends/capital gains may appear in AIS even if not in Form 16. Ensure you include all taxable income and match TDS.

items.name: Claiming HRA without evidence
items.insight: If you claim HRA, ensure you can substantiate rent payment and tenancy details.

items.name: Assuming declarations = proofs
items.insight: Employer declarations are not always sufficient; keep proof documents even if not submitted during payroll.

items.name: Forgetting to update regime choice
items.insight: If a regime requires explicit selection/opt-in in your filing workflow, ensure the choice is consistent with your computation and Form 16.

items.name: Not checking bank interest
items.insight: Savings/FD interest can trigger mismatches. Consider reconciling with AIS/26AS and your bank statements.

blocks.title: Primary references to consult
blocks.description: For compliance-critical decisions, consider verifying via official sources.

items.name: Income-tax Department (e-Filing portal)
items.note: ITR instructions, AIS/TIS, Form 26AS

items.name: CBDT notifications/circulars
items.note: Regime rules, deduction conditions

items.name: Union Budget documents
items.note: Slab changes, standard deduction updates

decoder.name: The Default Regime (New)
decoder.insight: New Regime offers very low tax rates but disallows HRA, LTA, 80C, 80D, etc. Standard Deduction of 75,000 is allowed.
decoder.action: Break-even Point: If your total deductions (80C+HRA+Home Loan+80D) are LESS than 3.75 Lakh, New Regime is mathematically better.

decoder.name: Old Regime
decoder.insight: Best for people with high HRA (living in metros), Home Loans (Interest up to 2L), and full 80C usage. You must explicitly 'Opt-In' for this every year while filing ITR.
decoder.action: Calculate carefully. Don't blindly stick to Old Regime just because you have insurance policies.

sections.name: Section 80C (Beyond LIC)
sections.items: EPF + VPF is the best debt instrument. ELSS is the best equity instrument. PPF is good for long term.
sections.insight: Don't buy 5% return Endowment plans to save 30% tax. You lose money in inflation.

sections.name: HRA Paying Parents
sections.insight: You can pay rent to parents and claim HRA if: 1) You actually transfer money via bank. 2) Parents declare it as 'Income from House Property' in their ITR. 3) You don't own the house.
sections.action: Create a formal Rent Agreement with parents.

sections.name: LTA Block Years
sections.insight: You can claim LTA exemption for 2 journeys in a block of 4 years. Travel must be within India. Only travel fare (Air/Rail) is exempt, not hotel/food.
sections.action: Keep boarding passes. Ticket printouts are not enough for audit.

rules.insight: LTCG up to 1.25 Lakh per year is tax-free. If you have profits, sell your shares to book 1.25L profit and buy them back immediately.
rules.benefit: You reset your buying price (step-up cost basis) and pay ZERO tax legally.

rules.insight: If you gift money to a non-working spouse to invest, the income generated is clubbed with YOUR income. Exception: Investing in PPF (tax-free) or investing money for marriage expenses.
rules.action: Loan money to spouse at nominal interest instead of gifting to avoid clubbing.

Business Loan.note: Short 12 yrs; medium up to 5 yrs

Plot Loan.note: Around 515 yrs; some up to 20 yrs

research.json.title: Research & Methodology
research.json.headline: Built on credible research, enhanced with AI for clarity
research.json.description: Bharat Finance Hub uses carefully curated, India-focused research for each asset class. We summarize complex assumptions into clear defaults so you can move fast, while staying transparent about how numbers are derived. AI helps synthesize sources and keep explanations concise and consistent.

financial.title: Financial instruments
financial.description: Scenario-based 5Y expected CAGR for equity categories, debt regimes post-2023, gold (spot/ETF/SGB), and REITs/InvITs. Tax models and payout assumptions are applied where relevant to estimate post-tax outcomes.

real_estate.title: Real estate
real_estate.description: City and pan-India residential appreciation estimates with rental yield defaults. Agricultural land baseline appreciation and lease yield defaults. Commercial properties include cap rate regimes, NOI growth, vacancy cycles, and capex allowances for realistic projections.

rental_yield.title: Rental yield math (residential)
rental_yield.description: We estimate net rental yield starting from gross rent, then apply realistic frictions to reach NOI (net operating income).
rental_yield.gross_yield: Gross yield = Annual rent / Property value
rental_yield.vacancy: Vacancy = Months empty per year (city default). Effective rent = Gross rent  (1  vacancy%)
rental_yield.operating_costs: Operating costs = Society/maintenance + minor repairs. Capex allowance = periodic big-ticket upgrades (paint, appliances, AC, etc.)
rental_yield.net_yield: Net yield = (Effective rent  Operating costs  Capex allowance) / Property value
rental_yield.noi_growth: NOI growth = City default for rent growth; you can override in Advanced.
rental_yield.city_vs_pan: City vs pan-India: When a city is selected, we use that city's rental yield, vacancy, and rent-growth defaults. If no city is set, we fall back to pan-India baselines.

precious_metals.title: Precious metals & alternatives
precious_metals.description: Scenario bands for precious metals and alternative assets. We translate instrument-level costs (ETF expense, tracking) and wrappers (SGB coupon/basis) into expected return ranges.

depreciating_assets.title: Depreciating assets
depreciating_assets.description: Age-based depreciation curves with floors and usage adjustments. Vehicles include segment-specific baselines, EV battery health considerations, and km/year/accident modifiers.

methodology.title: Methodology & AI use
methodology.evidence_desc: Defaults are anchored to Indian indices, RBI publications, market data, and reputable industry reports.
methodology.scenario_desc: We present bear/base/bull bands and compute scenario-weighted expectations to avoid point-estimate overconfidence.
methodology.transparent_desc: We show a short "Assumptions" explainer where it matters and let you override in Advanced controls if desired.
methodology.ai_desc: AI helps synthesize sources, maintain consistency, and explain assumptions. It does not replace human judgment or your personal circumstances.

sources.title: Key sources
sources.rbi: RBI: FRB, monetary policy reports, term deposit trends
sources.sebi: SEBI/AMFI: mutual fund categories, expense ratios
sources.nhb: NHB/CREDAI/JLL: real estate city indices, rental yields, cap rates
sources.mof: MoF schemes: PPF/SSY/SCSS parameters and changes
sources.market: Market data: gold (MCX/LBMA), REIT/InvIT disclosures, bond markets
sources.versions: Full dataset versions: Financial {{financial}}; Real Estate {{realEstate}}; Precious & Alternatives {{precious}}; Depreciating {{depreciating}}.

research.json.disclaimer: Estimates, not advice. Always validate critical decisions for your specific context.

fd.label: FD (Custom)
fd.note: Custom bank/corporate FD. Set payout/tenure/rate as needed.

pomis.label: POMIS
pomis.note: Post Office Monthly Income Scheme. Monthly payout; principal at 5 years.

nsc.label: NSC
nsc.note: National Savings Certificate. Annual compounding; maturity at 5 years.

kvp.label: KVP
kvp.note: Kisan Vikas Patra. Cumulative; doubles in notified period.

potd.label: Post Office TD
potd.note: Post Office Term Deposit. Yearly compounding; select 1/2/3/5 years.

scss.label: SCSS
scss.note: Senior Citizen Savings Scheme. Quarterly payout; 5-year term.

mssc.label: Mahila Samman Savings Certificate
mssc.note: Mahila Samman Savings Certificate. 2-year term; quarterly compounding.

frb.label: RBI Floating Rate Savings Bond (FRB)
frb.note: Floating rate: coupon = NSC rate + spread. Semi-annual payout; 7-year maturity. Rate resets periodically.

pmvvy.label: PMVVY (10Y annuity)
pmvvy.note: Pradhan Mantri Vaya Vandana Yojana. 10-year annuity-style payout; select payout mode in UI (monthly/quarterly/...).

custom.label: RD (Custom)
custom.note: Set your own rate and term.

ssy.label: Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana
ssy.note: Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana. Govt-notified interest rate; maturity at 21 years.

ppf.label: Public Provident Fund
ppf.note: Public Provident Fund. 15-year lock-in; tax-free interest.

apy.label: Atal Pension Yojana (APY)
apy.note: Atal Pension Yojana (APY). 25 years till pension start at age 60.

pmsym.label: PM-SYM
pmsym.note: Pradhan Mantri Shram Yogi Maandhan (PM-SYM). For unorganized sector workers.

gsec.label: G-Sec
gsec.note: Government Securities and State Development Loans. Typically 6-7% yield with semiannual payouts.

taxfree_psu.label: Tax-Free PSU
taxfree_psu.note: Tax-Free PSU Bonds. Interest exempt from income tax. Typically 5.5-8.5% yield.

corp_ig.label: Corporate (IG)
corp_ig.note: Investment-Grade Corporate Bonds. Higher yield than G-Secs, typically 7-9%.

ncd_hy.label: NCD (High Yield)
ncd_hy.note: High-Yield Bonds and NCDs. Higher risk, higher return, typically 9-12%+.

at1.label: AT1 / Perp
at1.note: AT-1 Perpetual Bonds. Bank-issued with call features, typically 8-8.5% yield.

sgb.label: Sovereign Gold Bond
sgb.note: Sovereign Gold Bonds. Gold price-linked with 2.5% p.a. interest.
